G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, which authorize the Probate and Family Court to modify judgments relating to custody and visitation when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, which authorize the Probate and Family Court to modify judgments relating to custody and visitation when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.proposition: The governing standard for custody modification in Massachusetts requires a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances, and (2) that modification will serve the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general custody-modification standard case. The court focuses on the "cause shown" requirement for removal and equates that with a best-interests-of-the-child analysis, but it does not articulate or apply a two-part standard requiring (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) best interests as the governing test for custody modification generally. The proposition thus overstates what Mason holds and cites it for the wrong doctrinal point.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Courts have held that exposure to domestic violence or unstable living conditions constitutes a sufficient change in circumstances to warrant modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion is about modification of custody and relocation where both parents are appropriate caregivers; it does not involve domestic violence or unstable living conditions as the change in circumstances. In fact, the court finds there was no material and substantial change in circumstances warranting a custody modification, and it emphasizes that both homes are safe and secure. Thus, it does not establish that exposure to domestic violence or unstable living conditions is a sufficient change in circumstances for modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: "There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which, on all of the uncontested evidence, had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995. To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker. The probate judge took note of the fact that both parents love the child, and that ‘both parents have safe and secure homes.’"

Care and Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass..raw_text: Care and Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (2004)
Care and Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass..proposition: Courts have held that exposure to domestic violence or unstable living conditions constitutes a sufficient change in circumstances to warrant modification.
Care and Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a care-and-protection/fitness case, not a modification proceeding, and it does not discuss the legal standard for modification based on changed circumstances. While it mentions the mother’s “nomadic lifestyle” and unstable housing as part of the unfitness analysis and discusses domestic violence in relation to custody, it nowhere holds or suggests that exposure to domestic violence or unstable living conditions constitutes a sufficient change in circumstances to warrant modification of an existing order. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modification standards.
Care and Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The judge also found, with substantial support in the record, that the mother was addicted to Vicodin and abused Valium. … Finally, the judge focused on the mother’s frequent moves with the child. While the child was in her mother’s physical custody, from November, 2000, to July, 2001, the pair resided in at least four different locations…. The evidence before the judge, reflected in the judge’s ninety-one findings of fact and seventeen conclusions of law, establish the mother’s parental unfitness clearly and convincingly.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 401–02 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The Court’s paramount consideration is the safety, stability, and welfare of the children.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody determinations the court’s overriding concern is the promotion of the children’s best interests and general welfare, and then applies that welfare-focused standard throughout its custody and visitation analysis. While it does not use the exact words “safety” and “stability,” its discussion of avoiding conflict, ensuring a healthy environment, and minimizing disruption clearly reflects that the paramount consideration is the children’s welfare and stable well-being.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Court’s paramount consideration is the safety, stability, and welfare of the children.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly grounds its analysis in the traditional Massachusetts rule that custody decisions turn on the child’s best interests, described in terms of welfare and stability. It emphasizes that the best-interests standard is the paramount concern and discusses at length the importance of preserving stable, satisfactory existing arrangements as a major component of the child’s welfare. This directly supports a formulation that the court’s paramount consideration in custody disputes is the safety, stability, and welfare of the children.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children… (‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’). … Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child….”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: The presence of a cohabitant with a violent criminal background may justify restrictions on visitation or requirements for supervision.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether identical twins should be split between parents in a custody modification and focuses on sibling separation, children’s preferences, and parental fitness. While the mother’s modification complaint mentioned danger from the father’s older son who had been arrested and hospitalized, the appellate decision does not analyze, adopt, or apply any rule about restricting visitation or requiring supervision due to a cohabitant’s violent criminal background. That issue plays no role in the holding or legal reasoning, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: Her complaint alleged a material change in circumstances: the twins had been placed “in physical and emotional danger in their father’s home due to the presence of their father’s oldest child [by a previous marriage], a son . . . who has recently been arrested for use of a firearm and committed to a mental hospital.” In December, 1994, the parties stipulated that, commencing in January, 1995, each parent would have physical custody of both children for alternating two-week periods and that, when the twins were staying with the father, his oldest son would not be left alone with them.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The presence of a cohabitant with a violent criminal background may justify restrictions on visitation or requirements for supervision.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on choosing between two adoption placements (a foster mother and a paternal aunt) based on the child’s best interests, developmental needs, stability, and familial relationships. It does not discuss visitation rights, restrictions on visitation, supervision of visitation, or the effect of a cohabitant’s violent criminal background on visitation conditions. Because the decision never addresses cohabitants’ criminal history or visitation limitations, it cannot be cited as authority for the stated proposition.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(a).proposition: Under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and G.L. c. 208, § 31, the Court may impose conditions necessary to safeguard the children’s best interests, including limitations on third-party contact during parenting time.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and G.L. c. 208, § 31, the Court may impose conditions necessary to safeguard the children’s best interests, including limitations on third-party contact during parenting time.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: The mandate of G.L. c. 208, § 31A (regarding abuse prevention) reinforces that custody and parenting determinations must protect children from exposure to domestic violence or abusive situations.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: As explained in Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) and Smith v. Jones, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 129 (2006), the Court has broad equitable authority to modify parenting time when required by new circumstances affecting the welfare of the children.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: Hunter v. Rose discusses standards for awarding initial custody and parenting schedules based on the child’s best interests, but it does not address the court’s equitable authority to later modify parenting time in response to new or changed circumstances. The opinion affirms the trial judge’s original custody and visitation determinations and notes they may be adjusted if Rose returns to Massachusetts, but it does not frame this in terms of broad equitable modification power or a legal standard for postjudgment modification. Thus it does not support the specific proposition cited.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt:
Moreover, the judge stated that, should Rose decide to move back to Massachusetts, the parties must work in good faith to adjust their parenting plan to meet Jill’s best interests.13

There was no abuse of discretion in determining that primary physical custody of Jill should be with the plaintiff.

Smith v. Jones, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 129 (2.raw_text: Smith v. Jones, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 129 (2006)
Smith v. Jones, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 129 (2.proposition: As explained in Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) and Smith v. Jones, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 129 (2006), the Court has broad equitable authority to modify parenting time when required by new circumstances affecting the welfare of the children.
Smith v. Jones, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 129 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Smith v. Jones is a G.L. c. 209A abuse‑prevention order case and does not involve custody, visitation, or parenting time, nor does it discuss the court’s equitable authority to modify parenting schedules due to changed circumstances. Its analysis is confined to the statutory definition of “abuse,” standards for issuance and extension of 209A orders, mootness, and expungement. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that courts have broad equitable power to modify parenting time based on new circumstances affecting children’s welfare.
Smith v. Jones, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 129 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Pursuant to G. L. c. 209A, §§ 3 and 4, a judge may impose certain orders, among others, requiring that a defendant refrain from abusing, refrain from contacting or merely stay away from a plaintiff upon a showing by a preponderance of the evidence… that he or she is ‘suffering from abuse.’ … The statute is not a general catch-all for the regulation of all human relationships that run into difficulty, no matter how compelling some of those difficulties may objectively be or subjectively seem.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: See also Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988); Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006) (all affirming the court’s continuing jurisdiction to alter custody orders when new conditions materially affect the child).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: This opinion deals with an appeal from an initial custody judgment and a remand for further findings regarding domestic violence; it does not discuss or affirm the court’s *continuing* jurisdiction to modify existing custody orders when new conditions arise. The only reference to changed circumstances appears in a footnote noting that three years have passed and the judge may wish to reassess the arrangement, but this is procedural guidance, not a holding on continuing modification jurisdiction. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “As almost three years have gone by since the Probate Court issued its judgment and Vaughn is now almost fourteen years of age, it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference and for the judge to evaluate the success of the stipulated custody arrangement the parties have been living under in the interim.”

Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mas.raw_text: Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988)
Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mas.proposition: See also Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988); Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006) (all affirming the court’s continuing jurisdiction to alter custody orders when new conditions materially affect the child).
Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion involves a care and protection judgment that was later modified (the judge vacated the no-contact provision and apparently returned physical custody while DSS retained legal custody), but the decision does not discuss or affirm the court’s *continuing jurisdiction* to alter custody orders upon materially changed circumstances as a legal principle. The later modification is mentioned only in a footnote as procedural history, not as a holding or articulated rule about ongoing jurisdiction. Thus it does not substantively support the stated proposition.
Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “In December, 1986 (about six and one-half months after judgment was entered), on motion of the mother (G. L. c. 119, § 26 [1986 ed.]), the judge vacated that part of the judgment that directed that there be no contact between Benjamin and the man who had been living with the mother. The change was made to permit the DSS’s service plan, which included ‘family counseling,’ to go into full effect. The father’s brief reports that the mother now has physical custody of Benjamin pursuant to a modified order (but the DSS still has legal custody).”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: See also Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988); Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006) (all affirming the court’s continuing jurisdiction to alter custody orders when new conditions materially affect the child).
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the court’s *continuing jurisdiction* to alter custody orders when new conditions materially affect the child. Pizzino v. Miller is a removal/modification case focused on application of the Yannas "real advantage" test and on whether the mother’s remarriage constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28. While it discusses what qualifies as a post‑divorce "material and substantial change," it does not address or affirm the existence or scope of the court’s ongoing jurisdiction to modify custody orders; that jurisdiction is simply assumed. Thus it does not provide direct authority for the jurisdictional proposition stated.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce … , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”
